# eslint/no-dupe-keys <Badge type="info" text="Correctness" />

<div class="rule-meta">
<Alert class="default-on" type="success">
<span class="emoji">âœ…</span> This rule is turned on by default.
</Alert>
</div>

### What it does

Disallow duplicate keys in object literals

### Why is this bad?

Multiple properties with the same key in object literals can cause
unexpected behavior in your application.

It is safe to disable this rule when using TypeScript because
TypeScript's compiler enforces this check.

### Example

Examples of **incorrect** code for this rule:

```js
var foo = {
  bar: "baz",
  bar: "qux",
};

var foo = {
  "bar": "baz",
  bar: "qux",
};

var foo = {
  0x1: "baz",
  1: "qux",
};
```

Examples of **correct** code for this rule:

```js
var foo = {
  bar: "baz",
  qux: "qux",
};
```

## How to use

To **enable** this rule in the CLI or using the config file, you can use:

::: code-group

```bash [CLI]
oxlint --deny no-dupe-keys
```

```json [Config (.oxlintrc.json)]
{
  "rules": {
    "no-dupe-keys": "error"
  }
}
```

:::
